review.title: Strategy Selection in Influence Diagrams using Imprecise Probabilities
review.abstract: This paper describes a new algorithm to solve the decision making problem in Influence Diagrams based on algorithms for credal networks. Decision nodes are associated to imprecise probability distributions and a reformulation is introduced that finds the global maximum strategy with respect to the expected utility. We work with Limited Memory Influence Diagrams, which generalize most Influence Diagram proposals and handle simultaneous decisions. Besides the global optimum method, we explore an anytime approximate solution with a guaranteed maximum error and show that imprecise probabilities are handled in a straightforward way. Complexity issues and experiments with random diagrams and an effects-based military planning problem are discussed.

metadata.title: Strategy Selection in Influence Diagrams using Imprecise Probabilities

sections.text: This paper describes a new algorithm for solving the decision problem in influence diagrams based on algorithms for faith networks. Decision nodes are associated with imprecise probability distributions and a reformulation is introduced that finds the global maximum strategy in terms of expected benefits. We work with limited memory influence diagrams that generalize most suggestions for influence diagrams and handle simultaneous decisions. Besides the global optimal method, we examine a solution that is always approximate with a guaranteed maximum error and show that imprecise probabilities are handled in an easy way. Complexity problems and experiments with random diagrams and an effects-based military planning problem are discussed.

sections.text: A limited influence by their parents (C) is represented by a directed acyclic graph (V, E) in which nodes are divided into three types: chance, decision, and utility nodes. Let C, D, and U indicate the number of random, decision, and usage nodes, and let X = C. Links of E characterize dependencies between nodes. Explicitly, links to a random node indicate the likely dependence of the node on its parents; links to a decision node indicate what information is available to make such a decision, and links to usage nodes represent that a benefit to these parents cannot be considered (utility nodes may not have children). sections.text: We conduct two experiments with the method. sections.heading: 5.1 EBO MILITARY PLANNING
sections.text: In this section we describe the performance of our method in a hypothetical effects-based operations planning problem [11]. An influence diagram similar to the model described by Zhang and Ji [22] is used. Its graphics are shown in Figure 2. The goal is to win a war, which is represented by the hypothesis Node (at the top of Figure 2). Only below there are the subgoals Air superiority, Territorial Occupation and Commander surrender, which are directly related to the main objective. There are eleven decisions (represented by rectangles): destroy C2 stands for command and control), destroy radars, destroy communications, destroy storage destroy destroy assembly, destroy assemble destroy, capture board, use special forces.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we discuss a new idea for strategy selection in the influence diagrams. We work with the Limited Memory Influence Diagram as it generalizes many of the suggestions for influence diagrams. The main contribution is the reformulation of the problem as a creative network inference that enables us to find the global maximum strategy for small and medium influence diagrams. Experiments suggest that many cases can be dealt with accurately. As far as we know, no in-depth investigation of exact procedures has been conducted for this class of diagrams. Due to the characteristics of our method, a solution is available at all times with a maximum guaranteed error during calculations. It is clear that large diagrams need to be dealt with roughly. Nevertheless, our method has yielded results in the experiments carried out that exceed existing algorithms. Although more time is spent, many situations require a solution to be as good as possible while time is a secondary issue. The ability of our approach to set an upper limit for the problem is likewise not more valuable to the result with the U.
